subject: 2 interviews
header: Usually Perl developers don't get a lot of screen-time, but this week we have two interviews. One with Ribasushi, and the other one with Larry Wall.
If you don't have time to watch them right away, then save this issue of the Perl Weekly, and check out the interviews later during the week.

entries.title: Senior Applications Engineer
entries.text: Uniregistry is looking for a talented and passionate engineer to build and maintain a world-class registry and registrar. This position requires the ability to analyze and implement elegant solutions to complex problems while contributing to the development of reusable components

entries.title: Supporting the Perl Weekly?
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Would you like to support the Perl Weekly? Just $1 an issue from each one of the readers would be fine. Is this newsletter worth $1 an issue for you? You can set up a weekly donation via Gratipay.

entries.title: Foswiki 2.0.3 is released
Dive into the Global Historical Climatology Network data using Perl and SQL
entries.author: sinan_unur
entries.text: I always love to see real-world applications of Perl. I also find the results very interesting. Both the increase in temperature and the strange hump in the number of observations.

entries.title: Understanding Marpa-style action subs parameters
entries.author: ron_savage
entries.text: If you don't know what is Marpa, don't worry. The article starts with links to the introduction.

entries.title: Should we call it "Learning Perl 5"
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: Now that Perl 6 is going to be release within a few weeks brian d foy is wondering if the next edition of the "Learning Perl" book that deals with the Perl 5 syntax should say so in the title. Not surprisingly the Reddit discussion got quite long. People have strong opinions.

entries.title: Bootstrapping test infrastructure for mojo application using swat
entries.author: alexey_melezhik
entries.text: SWAT = Simple Web Application Test and following the Dancer example this time we can see an example testing a Mojolicious-based web application.

entries.title: Improved Syntax Highlighting in the Debugger
entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.text: If you do enough testing then you won't need much debugging, but if you do, you might want to see that in color.

entries.title: OOP - Object Oriented Perl
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: An introduction to the classical, hash-based OOP system of Perl.

entries.title: One more month in the 2015 CPAN PR Challenge
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: Let's end the year in a bang! If you have started the CPAN PR Challenged at the beginning of the year, and have not followed through, it is the time to do all the remaining tasks. There is no better time than 2 days before the dead-line! Except maybe 1 day before the dead-line.

entries.title: Perl Regular Expression Awesomeness
entries.author: ingy_dot_net
entries.text: Just by looking at the author you can expect that 'crazy' is an understatement.

entries.title: Sidef - A modern object-oriented programming language, implemented in Perl
entries.author: trizen
entries.text: I think it is the first time I hear about this, but it is a full programming language, ready for you to play with. It comes with a tutorial and with lots of examples. BTW Sidef is Nacre in Romanian. It is the Mother of Pearl.

entries.title: November 2015 Grant Proposals
entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: There are 4 proposals and one of them looks like a scam. I let you guess which one.

entries.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: November 10th-15th
entries.author: sawyer_x

entries.title: Triangulation 225 - Leo Laporte talks with Larry Wall
FLOSS Weekly 363 - DBIx::Class
entries.text: Randal Schwartz and Guillermo Amaral talk to Peter "ribasushi" Rabbitson, the maintainer of DBIC

entries.title: What one Christmas elf has been up to
entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.text: 60 out of 100 issues that are needed for the Christmas release were fixed. NFG improvements is just one subject. Normal Form Grapheme is an efficient way of providing strings at grapheme level. Apparently there is an example when Unicode standard and 'how people think' differs.

entries.title: A gentle crash course on Perl in London
entries.author: andrew_solomon
entries.text: Developers of all programming languages are invited to the London Perl Workshop on December 12. There will be a free 2 hour hands-on course with the highlights of Perl, its community and its ecosystem so that the attendees are well prepared when they encounter it in the wild.

entries.title: RT: Our Last Training of 2015 is Filling Up!
entries.text: The last public RT training session of 2015 in Chicago, IL on December 14-15.

entries.title: NICEPERL's lists
entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

entries.title: AngularJS: filter table created with ng-repeat
entries.author: gabor_szabo

entries.title: Jonathon Worthington to Keynote at London Perl Workshop
entries.author: mark_keating

entries.title: OSCON Call for Papers
entries.author: mark_keating
entries.text: The OSCON Call for Papers closes this Tuesday, 24th November, and at this moment there are no papers submitted on Perl. It would be a shame if the conference that started as The Perl Conference did not have any presentation about Perl.
